block.p: Domaine Wolffer Sagpond Vineyards, chardonnay reserve, Sagaponack, 1993. About $15.

Unlike some jack-in-the-box California chardonnay reserves -- uncork them and the flavor jumps out -- Sagpond's needs time to get ready for dinner. Open it 60 to 75 minutes in advance and let it breathe. The results can be rewarding.
Domaine Wolffer Sagpond Vineyards, chardonnay reserve, Sagaponack, 1993. About $15.

Unlike some jack-in-the-box California chardonnay reserves -- uncork them and the flavor jumps out -- Sagpond's needs time to get ready for dinner. Open it 60 to 75 minutes in advance and let it breathe. The results can be rewarding.

The well-financed Sagpond, on the South Fork, is owned by Christian Wolffer. Its estate-grown grapes -- 45 acres have been planted -- yielded their first wines in 1991. This is the second reserve prepared by Roman Roth, the German-born wine maker. It further refines the winery's Burgundian tendencies.
At least a year's cellaring would nurture the budding complexity of this medium-bodied barrel-fermented chardonnay. But the partying Hamptons are a drink-now place.

Today, the wine offers crisp acidity, modest fruit, moderate oakiness and yeastiness, a creamy texture (from the secondary fermentation) and, when fully aired, honey and butterscotch aromas and flavors. Serve it just barely cool. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG
